abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Loan (FSTAL) Project for Dominican
            Republic were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high, the
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: during difficult times and when
            there is limited implementation capacity it is important to
            keep the design of a project simple even if the project is
            smaller. This project was too complex with multiple
            implementing agencies. Given the limited experience with
            financial sector operations in the Dominican Republic the
            FSTAL should have been structured as a simple project with
            clean implementation arrangements or alternatively with a
            longer execution period and a phased approach, in which
            triggers will be established for each phase of
            implementation. If successful, a follow up operation or
            phases of a longer duration project could have maintained
            the continuity of institutional support while being more
            responsive to changing technical assistance (TA) needs over
            time. The best indicator of project sustainability is
            borrower engagement in follow-up operations. The FSTAL tried
            to address too many challenges in the financial system but
            it should have been more selective particularly with the
            high degree of uncertainty at the time of project design.
